review_body: About a 20 minute walk from Shinjuku station and just down the road from another subway stop (can’t recall which one), we had three rooms for two nights at a rate of around £110 per room per night. Nothing wrong with the hotel. Small rooms but that is standard for Tokyo as I understand it. It’s basically a business hotel (and I have previously stayed in the brand on business) and designed to be ‘long stay’. They pack a lot into a small space and room had a (clothes) washing machine (and you are given detergent upon check-in), microwave, kettle and fridge. Comfortable bed, working wifi, decent shower, etc. There was a coffee machine in the lobby which provided drinkable coffee.Breakfast was included in our rate and fairly basic but staff kept everything topped up and, if it was empty, were happy to top up things upon request. There were a few western options including scrambled egg and bread. I’m not sure why this hotel has had so many negative reviews. We found the staff friendly and had reasonable English, were happy with the location and the facilities in the area (there is a MacDonalds next door, a convenience store across the road and several local restaurants within a couple of minutes walk! When we researched it, it seemed reasonable value and we were happy.

Firstly, this is not Tokyu Stay Shinjuku, we made that mistake and checked in to the wrong hotel initially. It is about 15 to 20mins walk away from the heart of Shinjuku (and its bursting night life). So we had to walk quite a bit to the train stations (nearest was Nishi Shinjuku about 10mins walk) each time we wanted to travel (and inconvenient with luggage).The room was very small (smallest I have ever stayed) - but that was quite expected in Tokyo I guess and at that price I am not sure if you will get any larger. Bed was comfortable and service was relatively good as they left new towels outside our room when we put a DND sign.They didn't provide mineral waters (usually complimentary) and no safe deposit box. No frills hotel but just didn't cut it for us.

It’s a clean hotel. But it is the most ”blah” place we’ve stayed at in Japan. The problem is, I trusted the 3-Star rating. This is definitely not 3-Star. This is comparable to a La Quinta Inn in the US. And yet it’s further away from any conveniences (subway stations, etc).The towels are so small and thin and scratchy. The tub/shower is teeny and cheap. I can see this being a nice place to stay for extended stays for business, as it has a suit press, microwave, washing machine dryer. But the room is teeny, the bed is very small, the room is so small, there is no service available.It’s very no frills and would have been fine had I known it was a 1 or 2 star. Then there would be no expectations. But when it claims to be 3-Star, I expect it to be more comfortable than what it is.

Great deal! Excellent neighborhood, clean room, comfortable bed, staff helpful and efficient. Microwave, wash machine, iron, locker and many amenities. The breakfast has many options but a few “ continental “ itens like toast, cheese, looks more oriental with rice, fish, soup etc.

Pros: - Very close to subway station, which gets you to Shinjuku station in 2 stops. - Clean room.- Staff tried to be helpful, when approached. Cons:- Transferring at Shinjuku station from the subway line to the JR line is not straightforward. - McDonalds next door, but otherwise limited food options in the area. - Breakfast area was undergoing renovations at the time of stay, so had to get breakfast elsewhere. - Staff did not have great english, but we got by. Nothing too special about this hotel, either positive or negative. Would consider staying again, depending on price.

I stayed at two other Tokyu Stay properties during my 2 weeks in Japan (both were excellent). I have to say this hotel was the worst. Once I stepped into the hotel, the lobby was being renovated. The hotel itself seemed run down and needed a major upgrade. The service was horrible. I felt at the other two Tokyu Stays the front desk staff was always friendly and saying “good morning” or “hello” every time they would see us, that was not the case here. Everytime we would come thru the lobby we werent acknowledged. The cleaning ladies were friendly though. The staff also seemed annoyed at any questions we had. The coffee machine wasnt working properly in the lobby and my husband tried to use it, none of the staff bothered to help. Also, I am convinced the sheets hadnt been washed because I had a few bites on my body and was very itchy after sleeping in the bed. The hotel policy states they didnt clean rooms or fix beds for less than 1 week stay, the staff would only take out trash/replace towels, however the recyclables were never taken out! We had a whole pile we separated from the trash of plastic bottles that was never taken out during our 6 day stay here. The trash was taken out but not the bottles. I thought that was rather absurd since its part of their daily trash policy and the room was rather small (the bottles took up alot of space). The only plus to this hotel was that there were several convience stores and fast food places within walking distance. Overall, I had a poor experience at this Tokyu Stay location and will not be returning.

This hotel does NOT make restaurant reservations in advance of check-in. Concierge service is the only way to get a table at many of the good restaurants in Tokyo as a foreigner. Despite having paid for our 5 day stay in advance, they refused to do it. I am extremely disappointed.

Stayed here after I booked the wrong hotel. Staff was completely friendly and spoke great English. Rooms were incredibly spacious for Tokyo, came with its own washer and dryer! Location was fantastic, easy access to everything with great restaurants close by. Ended up staying at a 4-star hotel for the rest of my stay in Tokyo. I wished I'd stayed here longer.

Reasonably priced hotel and this is not easy to find in Shinjuku area.Not huge but conveniently located. Seems to be much more busy on week days; not many people had breakfast on Saturday / Sunday so probably more business hotel. Staff is friendly and speak good English.We had a problem with washing machine and although it was late at night we did get help.Breakfast does not spoil you with choice but gives you enough variety and is really cheap so no complains there.Really good value for money.Rooms are clean, average size with electric kettle, microwave and washing machine/dryer.Remember that sheets are changed once a week and the bin is also emptied once a week but that was not a problem.Coffee machine and internet stand in a lobby.Very good location not only to explore Shinjuku and Shibuya areas but also for one day trips around Tokyo.Shinjuku station is 15/20 minutes walk away. Station is huge and not easy to navigate but be patient - after couple of days you will crack it.- Nishi-shinjuku-gochome subway station is closest (3 minutes walk) but be aware that this line (Oedo) is not one of Tokyo Metro lines. It is operated by Toei Subway which means that you can not board with Tokyo metro pass. You have to buy pass for both operators. We did usually walk 10 minutes to Nishi-shinjuku station on Marunouchi Line instead. If you have JR Pass and you don't want to spend extra money on tube tickets/pass it still can be done. There are two JR lines available in Shinjuku station: Yamanote line and Chuo line - both extremely useful. Yamanote line is a loop going to most interesting areas and Chou line will get you quickly to Tokyo station area.- Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building with free observation deck is just 10 minutes away. There are usually long queues (30 minutes wait) but staying nearby has an advantage; you can go early morning or late evening and avoid crowd.- 24/7 shop called Maruetsu Petit is 5 minutes away and is much bigger than Family Mart of 7/11; we haven't discovered it straight away but it proved to be very handy. You can find European style bread there.- if you miss international food McDonald's is in the same building and Denny's is 5 minutes away.Easy transport to/from Narita airport; JR Narita Express goes directly to Shinjuku ststion.From Shinkuku station you can catch direct trains to Kamakura, Mount Takao, Hakone and Nikko (trains to Nikko do not go often so check before travelling) so staying nearby is a big advantage.Overall very good place to stay and explore Tokyo.

This is a reasonably priced hotel for Tokyo. The staff are always friendly and welcoming. Rooms are a decent size for Japan and are equipped with a washing machine and dryer. No iron or ironing board but there's an electric trouser press. Breakfast was Japanese style so no bacon and eggs, very good all the same. Would use this place again.

Superstylish hotel with a lot of minimalistic and modern artifacts around the lobby. The rooms are cool and modern but still with a asian touch. We had transfer included in our stay which made it all great.

Our party of 3 stayed for 3 nights. We all had king single beds with plenty of room for bags without tripping over them. Kitchen and bathroom facilities were good. Loved the robes, and slippers for use. Breakfast at 500 yen was good value offering a range of choices. The service from the front desk was exceptional- they helped with directions, maps, subway information and their English made it easy to understand. The subway is close - 2 minute walk. The hotel is near a park, close the Tokyo Metropolitan observation building offering free access to the 45 floor viewing level. Would recommend this hotel to others.

Stayed two nights in the semi double room at close to SGD180 per night - their semi double rooms are slightly larger than the usual, at 18 sqm - fine for two people with two suitcases. Room was functional, but feels quite like a business hotel overall. Picked this for the location, convenient to explore shinjuku, shibuya and the surroundings. From Shinjuku Station, take the Oedo Line, two stops to Nishi-Shinjuku-gochome Station, and walk about 240m to the hotel. No lack of convenience stores nearby. The Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building is also 700m away - go for great views for free. Cheapest / most cost effective way to get to Narita Airport from this hotel: walk to Nishi-shinjuku-gochome Station, take Oedo Line to Daimon Station, change to Asakusa Line (エアポート快特Narita-Airport) direct to Narita Airport. Takes about 1 h 40 minutes at 1380 yen, but do a search on specific timings of the train to the airport - doesn't depart regularly.

It is not easy to find a reasonable priced apartment in Tokyo. This apartment hotel offers small but good equipped rooms. The apartments provide a fully equipped kitchen, a comfortable bed, a bathroom with bathtub, air con, TV with local stations and fast WiFi. The hotel is located 2 minutes from the next subway station and not far from the Shinjuku railway station. Some restaurants and a supermarket are just accross the street.

Location of the hotel is great for exploring Shinjuku and it isn't far from the main Shinjuku Station. The metro station is also very close. Room was clean and comfortable. There is also a bus called the Airport Limousine for Haneda and Narita airports which stops at the Hilton Hotel just a couple of minutes walk away from this hotel.

Recently stayed here with my mum. We stayed 6 nights. Pretty good location, walking distance from 2 metro stations. PROs- Good location- Washing machine and dryer, and microwave in the room- new towels daily - even though it had a Japanese capsule bathroom it didn’t feel like it was one- free (good quality) coffee in reception - room not too small with a window- secure, no street noiseCONs- window covering doesn’t keep out the morning light (needed to wear eye mask)- bed covers where made of something slippery so they kept falling off the bed in the middle on the night- air conditioner was very complicated to use, all the buttons are in Japanese and whenever you press a button the machine talks to you, also in Japanese, very frustrating to use- room only cleaned after 7 nights, it wasn’t that clean when we arrived with hair in the drain in the shower and a finger nail on the floor in the bathroom, and not having it cleaned while we were there meant it was starting to feel unclean by the time we left

In a very convenient area. You can find metro trains close by with a McDonald’s next door and 2 7eleven just down the road. Very clean, cosy abs friendly. Value for money and I’ll definitely go back! The rooms may have been small but the bed and shower were spacious.

The room was a good size, clean and tidy. The hotel breakfast was nothing special, but good value for the price. The subway nearby was handy and connected easily to other lines. We found the washer/dryer especially helpful. We would absolutely stay again.

The hotel is a few minutes walk from Nishi-shinjuku-gochome subway station but about a 15 minute walk from Shinjuku walk which is where you'd need to be to get anywhere of interest. It's a nice walk through the park but can be slightly annoying after a few days. The hotel is on the main road but in quiet area away from any noise. The room was clean but note that only the towels and bins are changed daily so if you also want your bed made daily then this is not the place for you! It was great having an in-room washing machine, I made sure to make full use of it.There are a few restaurants nearby, lots of convenience stores and a McDonald's right next door. Easy walking distance to the Government Metropolitan Building which offers free panoramic views of the city.

Very nice hotel, with friendly staff, 10 minutes walking distance to Shinjuku Station where you can take the jr bullet train and the yamanote line to go wherever you want in Tokyo.The only thing I disliked is that the breakfast was until 930 that is too early.

This is akin to your average western business hotel. The rooms are fairly spacious by Japanese standards and they're modern and clean. The staff are friendly and will help you use Takkyubin etc. should you ask. The hotel is quite far from Shinjuku train station (20-30 min walk) but taxis are plentiful as is uber. There is a subway nearby but it didn't go anywhere I was interested in going really. There are some nice little restaurants in the surrounding area if you can find them and there are some lovely parks nearby. There's also some good tourist attractions like the government offices nearby as well. I'd stay here again definitely.

Tiny. Dated. Dingy. Far from the subway. No amenities. No lobby bar. No shuttle to the airport. No bottles of water in the fridge. Late check-in at 3pm.We paid 23000 yen. So not worth it!!!We also stayed at the Hyatt and Keio for some other nights for another 10000 yen or so more and it was night and day.

had 4 nights recentlypositives - decent hotel and clean, nice complimentary breakfast, basic but good, close to a subway station to walk, area of the hotel is very safe and not bad at all but not many restaurants or bars around, negatives - not the best location, rooms are small, staff is ok but older men are not very friendly looks bit annoyed or grumpy when you ask for anything, ladies are nice.

I have no complaints about this hotel. The prices were really good and the rooms are bigger than average hotel rooms in Tokyo. Located in a really calm are but super-close to the metro which makes it easy to travel around Tokyo. They don't clean the rooms every day, but that was not a problem for us.

we stayed for one night to catch our early flight in Narita airport. it was around 11 am when we arrived. the staff let us store the luggage first. we came back after 3 pm and luggage were already in room. there were kitchenette and washing machine, we didn't use though. the bathroom size was larger than expected so that you won't hit yourself when turn around. bed was comfortable. we took 2 stops from Shinjuku-Gochome Station to Shinjuku JR for the Narita Express when leaving. the check-out process was quick and smooth.

I stayed at the Tokyu Stay Nishi-Shinjuku for just over 2 weeks on my most recent trip to Tokyo. It's the first time I have stayed here, and I chose it due to a combination of location, amenities and lower cost than other options I have tried.The first thing to note is that it's a mid-range Japanese business class hotel, not a luxury place, so if you have stayed in Japanese hotels before, that should give you an idea of what to expect. If you're new to Japan, then be aware that rooms tend to be on the small side, but are well equipped with most things one needs for a comfortable stay.With that said, Tokyu Stay Nishi-Shinjuku scores highly on room layout. I stayed in a single, but as those go, I found this one to be well designed, with space at the foot of the bed for empty suitcases and other items where they were not in the way. There was also a wooden box under the bed to supplement the small wardrobe, and a good sized desk incorporating a couple of drawers and a small room safe inside. I had no trouble accommodating 2 weeks worth of clothes and stuff conveniently.My room included a washer/dryer (you get one free sachet of washing powder and after that can buy more at 30 yen apiece from the front desk), a hairdryer, alarm clock, trouser press, small fridge, air purifier, large screen TV (with CNN International as the only English channel), kettle and microwave. There was also a plate, bowl, mug and a set of cutlery including a corkscrew and good ceramic knife provided in the room.The instructions for the washing machine are not very comprehensive in English but I managed okay and it was very handy. Any handwashed clothes dried quickly over the bath due to the excellent ventilation in the bathroom.The bed was a comfortable semi-double and the pillows were better than at many other places I have stayed in. The addition of a bolster for relaxing to watch TV was very welcome. Slippers and nightshirts were also provided and changed each week.Bathroom was clean and well stocked with shampoo, conditioner, bodywash, hand soap, toothbrush and toothpaste etc. Again, some of these items could be replenished from a supply in the lobby (for free). I was provided with 2 bath and 2 hand towels plus a bath mat per week, which was absolutely fine. Water pressure and temperature was good and generally the bathroom had a decent amount of space for personal items.If you stay for short visit, the hotel provides cleaning daily. However, if your visit is longer, cleaning is weekly only as standard. This means that sheets and towels etc are changed once a week, and the bin is also emptied only once a week. I made sure to return empty PET bottles to the convenience store where I bought them to ensure my bin did not overflow. Cleaning staff were polite and friendly and did an excellent job. Desk staff told me when I checked in what days the cleaning would be done and the schedule was exactly correct. Note that if you use the in room crockery this does mean that you have to wash it yourself after use. But you can get small bottles of dishwash liquid and washing cloths/brushes from neaby supermarkets for little cost and wash them in the bathroom sink as needed. I didn't find this at all onerous.Check in was easy and fast, as I had paid in advance when I booked. Staff throughout my stay were friendly but unobtrusive and generally had a good working standard of English. The hotel was great about storing my luggage until check in on the day I arrived, and also about receiving a parcel for me in advance of my arrival.There is free wifi on every floor and I found it fast and reliable for laptop and mobile devices. There were also a good number of sockets available in the room for electronics, both on the desk and on the small shelf above the bed.Free coffee is provided in the lobby from 10am to 11pm for guests, and this was a nice touch which I used most days. Access to the hotel proper is gained with the electronic room keys which ensures that only guests can access the elevator area, which I appreciated as a single female traveller.The other thing to note about this hotel is its location. It is NOT in the middle of the busy part of Shinjuku, but rather about 15 minutes walk west of Shinjuku Station, near the border of Hatsudai and the Nakano area, close to the Tokyo Metropolitan Government buildings. The closest station is Nishi-Shinjuku Go-Chome subway station which is a couple of minutes walk away. If you do not know this area of Tokyo well, and expect to be "in the middle of things" or don't like the idea of having to walk any distance on a regular basis, you may be disappointed. So please bear that in mind. However, if you want somewhere that's still very convenient for Shinjuku proper, while making a bit of a saving and being a little quieter in general, it's absolutely perfect. Tokyo is a safe city to walk in at all hours in general, and I did not encounter a single problem in this regard,The location is particularly good for access to Haneda airport, as you can get to it easily from the Go-Chome subway station using the Oedo line, changing at Daimon for the Monorail., It takes about 50 minutes. I also find the Oedo line pretty useful for a lot of sightseeing once you're used to the route of the railway line - in particular, you can take it to Yoyogi and change there for the Yamanote, thus avoiding the crowds of Shinjuku Station entirely. Go-Chome station has elevators on both levels from the street to the platforms.Lastly, I found the immediate area great for pharmacies, supermarkets (there are two within easy walking distance) and convenience stores. There are also some nice little eateries nearby, both independent and chain places. I loved the Okinawan place across the road called "Re:more". And next door is a 24 hour MacDonalds if you are desperate for hot food in the early hours! The nearby Shinjuku Central Park is lovely for eating outdoors on a quiet day.All in all I thoroughly enjoyed my stay and would happily book this hotel again.

I booked this hotel close to the Shinjuku station, but was not sure if I made a good choice. I was afraid the room and bed was going to be too small for 2 adults. But when we got there, this small hotel really impressed me. The room is small, but the double twin bed can fit 2 medium size adult with no problem. There is a refrigerator, a microwave, and even a washer/dryer combo that came in super handy. We prebooked the breakfast for $3.50 price person, they charging 500 yen there. Food was good, mostly western with meat, egg, salad, yogurt. The hotel is secure, you need the door key to enter the elevator room, the staff is friendly, and helpful. It is only 270 meter to the nearest subway station, and a short walk to the Shinjuku station. I recommend this hotel.

East Brunswick, New Jersey

review_body: This hotel is at the outskirt of Shinjuku but close to the subway (7 min walk) that are 2 stops from it. The room is small but as expected. As small as it is, it does have a washer & dryer in-room. We tried it, it took 2 hours but did get the work done. Staff is cordial but limited in English conversation. Breakfast is limited but costs only $5, beats McDonald's which is literally next door.

I have stayed at this hotel a total of 25+ nights on various occasions, sometimes short and sometimes longer. Generally I'm pleased because it's very practical and convenient. Beds are comfortable and it even has a washer/dryer in the room to deal with laundry. What I don't like is that the staff/management offers zero flexibility in any way. On my last reservation I arrived at the hotel at 1:45pm and was told if I want to check in before 3pm I'd have to pay a fee. After staying at the hotel more than 25 nights (where other chains give you a nice Platinum card with hard benefits) they actually wanted money for checking in roughly an hour before. Eventually they relented after I told management either I check in now or I will cancel my reservations and refund the money. The same goes for check-out, you can bet that as soon as the clock hits 11am someone will call your room asking you to check out. No, they won't wait until 11:05 or 11:10, they will call you at 11:01. Unbelievable!

Great, very clean hotel with very friendly and helpful staff. The room had a microwave, fridge, and washing machine/dryer making our stay very convenient. My friend and I enjoyed the 10-15minute walk to shinjuku station though there are also subways right next to the hotel. There is even a hidden shrine in the park across the road. The breakfast was good - a combination of western and traditional Japanese. There are some good restaurants right across the road as well as grocery and convenience stores. Would highly recommend.

We booked this as a reasonably priced option for our 2 nights in Tokyo.It's easy to find - next to the McDonalds - don't worry it's not busy or noisey.Check-in was quick and easy and the rooms are well sized and equipped with your own washing machine and kitchen facilities. We almost forgot all the amenities our rooms had when we arrived. I also had a great city skyline view from my 9th floor room.The breakfast buffet is good - not a huge selection but enough to cater for your needs with hot and cold options with juice, coffee etc. The nearest metro is a 2 min walk away and even from Narita airport the hotel is easy to get to.I would have no issues in staying here again if I was to return to Tokyo.

I was staying for 2 days in January 2017.I've got a room on the 10th floor and it was small but cosy. The amenities was good as it even came with a washer/dryer combination (which was one of the reasons I stayed there after a 3 weeks trip in the rest of Japan). As I had quite a number of laundry to wash, the front desk staff was kind enough to provide me an additional packet of powder detergent which was a really kind gesture.The hotel is also conveniently located next to a McDonald's so you won't go hungry at night. Further down the street, you can also locate a Sukiya shop across the road. As for the subway, it is located approximately 100m away from the Nishishinjuku-gochome station which is 2 stops away from Shinjuku (middle stop being Tochomae station). The trip to Shinjuku will cost you 180yen one way. However, for the budget traveller, you can also brisk walk for about 15 mins to Shinjuku station.All in all, the hotel has friendly and helpful staff and the hotel has provided me with a clean and well-equipped room for a good night's rest.

Just arrived Tokyo from Nagoya yesterday on New Year's Eve. Arrived early before checked in time so we just left our baggage at the hotel and went to shibuya waiting for countdown. When we came back at around 2am, just realized the blanket had a smell of Urine... we sprayed sanitizer and refresher to ease the smell...since we don't want to call housekeeping this late at night.They indicated there's no room cleaning the next day so we only asked them for new bedsheets and we will change it ourselves but the receptionist emphasized they won't do room cleaning....we told him that the blanket stinks and we only wanted to have new bedsheets and we will do it on our own and he replied us there's an extra charge for a blanket and a new bedsheet.We went down to ask for a comment sheet about this hotel and Mr. T. Akasaka continued to tell us that they don't do room cleaning...For the whole experience there's no even one apology for the stinky room. Be prepared if u come to Tokyu Stay Nishishijuku.

This hotel is more of a serviced apartment. We had a semi-double room because we booked it quite last minute and there were no twin rooms left. The room itself was very small and one of us had to open the luggage at the entrance while the other takes the space below the tv in front of the bed. There is only one small swivel chair so the other person will have to sit on the bed. The walkway to the bed from the entrance to the bed is so narrow only one person can walk through at any one time. Once the bathroom door opens outwards, the door blocks the walkway so the door needs to be closed all the time. There is no wardrobe provided. Only a bar with 5 hangers. However, I must say the room makes full use of the space efficiently. Despite its size, the room has a washing machine with dryer function, a microwave, a kitchenette with an electric stove and sink and a cabinet with a set of utensils and cutlery. The room is brand new and clean and the bathroom has a shower and tub. Check-in was quick and fuss free. Location wise, it is a 5 minute walk from Oedo subway station Nishishinjuku-chome. It is a 15-20 minute walk from Shinjuku Station's West Exit. Tokyo Metropolitan Government Office and the Shinjuku Central Park are within walking distance. There are several eateries nearby and McDonald's is just beside it. There are also quite a few convenience stores nearby so it is not quiet. The pillows are quite hard but you can request for softer ones. They change the towels and bathrobes, empty the trash and replace basic toiletries everyday. They do not make your beds unless you stay beyond a certain number of days. But that is fine by us. Counter staff was friendly and speaks fairly good English. I would definitely stay there again but probably try to get a twin room next.

The hotel is nestled in a very good location, where you can walk for some important attractions of Tokyo and coffee shop to have breakfast also. Also, there is a subway station near by.I just was unlucky that my room was the smallest category the hotel, and the hotel didn't have rooms above my category available for upgrade. So that, my stay was a little bit stressed because I was traveling with someone else and 4 luggages.But the hotel is very clean and the staff is nice.In case you want to stay here, I recommend only if you are not carrying big luggages and don't lose the key card room to avoid to pay the fine that is 40 dollars per card.Internet is free and also, they provide some nice amenities as: toothbrush,dental paste, etc.

This was a combination business/vacation for one week. I was in a double room for 3 days and then a single for the next 3. I try not to stay in the they same place every time I go to Tokyo but I have now learned my lesson. This place needs a thorough cleaning. The carpet was dirty and ripped in my first room, the carpet in the hallways are also very dirty. Worst of all was the Mildew in both bathrooms....unacceptable!

Loved staying at this hotel. The location was perfect to stay in. It is definitely near to subway stations and train Station , as well as shopping centers. The staff were very professional and accommodating. The hotel offered breakfast and it was standard for the asian palate. The location of the hotel is near Parks, Buddhist temples, and accessible to different metro stations. I would definitely stay here again.

Its close to the subway ( nishishinjuku gochome) rooms are average. They are not changing beds sheets everyday ( only towels) What we liked is that we has washer-dryer and micro in the room. Its a bit far from shinjuku station but with subway its not big deal. Close to starbucks and denny's

I stayed here with my grandma for the first night of our trip and it was great!The beds were comfortable which was much needed after our flight. Staff were very friendly and spoke good english which is always a plus.The location is great, only a few minutes down the street to the subway station and many nice restaurants.We have already booked our last night here before flying home because it was that convenient.

This is a great base to explore Tokyo. It is a short walk from the metropolitan government building and it's great views and our room had an excellent view of the building itself. Staff are friendly and the nearest metro station is just five minutes walk. Good places to eat locally. Recommended!

My wife and I stayed at this hotel and couldn't recommend it more. We spent a bit more in this hotel but it was completely worth the price. We only wished we had stayed all whole stay in Tokyo in this location.Also the staff was absolutely perfect. Just to give you an idea, I mistakenly forgot my ipad in the room when I left, the staff was super professional and sent me the ipad straight away to my next hotel in Japan.I wouldn't hesitate in booking a room in this location at all.

Loved the amenities such as wasing machine and press iron, it has its own kitchenette with microwave. The buffet breakfast is good and they serve flowing coffee all-day! The hotel is near a subway station

Ideally located and set in a quieter part of busy of Tokyo yet easy access to the metro which takes a few minutes to reach the center.The room we had was decent in size but not large. Had everything we needed. Clean and modern. Lovely staff. Free wifi. Overlooks the park. Perfect choice for our 2 night Tokyo stay! Recommended!

Location is excellent. On arrival they provide you with all the amenities you need including toothbrushes and tooth paste which were nice touches. The bathroom was very spacious and the room much bigger then expected for Tokyo. Very happy with the stay and the service was excellent.

This hotel is conveniently located close to Shinjuku, but with a certain distance, so you can live away from the crowd. Its cleanness meets my expectaion of the Japanese hotels. I love one of the room facility the most-- washing machine. You can just have all your dirty clothes washed before you head to home.

This hotel is conveniently located just a 3 min. walk to Nishi-shinjuku gochome station and a 15 min. walk to Shinjuku station. I flew into Haneda, but did not take the metro to the hotel. Instead I took a limousine bus to Hilton which is just a couple minutes from and then walked to the hotel. Close to convenient stores where you can grab q quick bite, as well as restaurants nearby. There's also a McDonalds next door that is open 24hr. There's even a park and shrine across the street.I got a single occupancy, non-smoking room. Room is clean; however, if you stay less than a week, you only get your towels changed daily. Room is equipped with a washer, with English directions on how to use, linen press, a microwave, tv, and fridge. A robe and room slippers were also provided. Bed was comfortable, although I could've used a couple more pillows. I used the house shampoo, conditioner, and body wash that came standard in the shower. You can even grab free toothpaste, toothbrush, brush, razor, at the ground elevator. I didn't have to pack my own. Great for those travelers on the go.Aside from the bidet, the coolest thing in the bathroom was the heated mirror which prevented the glass from fogging. So impressed! Room key also activated the use of the elevator and the lights in the room. You can also enjoy a daily buffet breakfast at a cost of about 500 yen or $5 US. I didn't take the offer as there were many eateries around. The front desk and staff were vey helpful and friendly.

We stayed here for one night as we moved our flight a day later and our prior hotel was fully occupied the final night.Pros:-room is decent size -free fast wifi-room is well equipped. Came with washer/drying machine, microwave, pressing machine for pants, etc-24/7 McDonald's downstairs -free coffee machine in lobby Average:-we were staying in a hotel closer to shinjuku station before which was a lot more convenient. This hotel is about a 10min walk from the local subway. But you'd often have to make connections to another line -area is a bit more quiet compared to right by shinjuku station. Less restaurants etc. Since the price is fairly similar, I think I'd rather stay a little closer to shinjuku. But overall a decent hotel

This hotel is very conveniently located near to Nishishinjuku metro station and is in a good part of the city. The rooms are small and the provisions are pretty basic (certainly this is no four star hotel as advertised). However, it is clean, quiet and the staff are friendly so I don't really have any complaints

Our family of four (2 adults, 1 child and 1 baby) stayed at TokyuStay NIshi-Shinjuku for 6 nights, and found the hotel to be comfortable and convenient for travelling with young children. We would definitely stay here again.The hotel is located in the quieter side of Shinjuku, about a 10-15min walk (uphill) to the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building. It is about a 5min walk from the Nishi-Shinjuku Gochome station, which is 2 stops (approx. 5mins) on the Toei Oedo train line from the Shinjuku station. This station conveniently has lifts from the platform to the street, which were very useful when traveling with a stroller. The surrounding neighbourhood is quiet at night - you'll need to head to the eastern side of Shinjuku for bars and nightlife - but there are still plenty of places to eat nearby. The hotel thoughtfully provided a map with the location of nearby restaurants. There are also a number of 7-11 and 7-11 type stores and a pharmacy within 5mins walk of the hotel.We stayed in a Twin Room B room, which was large and spacious by Japanese hotel standards. There were two comfortable double beds, though the pillows took some getting used to (my husband ended up requesting a different type). Our daughter shared a bed with me at no extra charge, while the baby had his portacot (we brought our own as the hotel did not supply them). The room had a small kitchenette with a sink, small fridge (with separate freezer), microwave, electric hotplate, kettle and a combination washer/dryer (with English instructions). We found the latter to be a godsend - it was used every day of our stay. The first packet of detergent was complimentary, and subsequent packets could be purchased for 30yen each from the very friendly and helpful staff at the hotel reception. The bathroom was compact and was equiped with a shower over a small bathtub and a fancy Japanese toilet/bidet. The shower curtain was annoying but the water pressure was awesome. There was also a large flat screen tv in the room, but only one English-language channel (CNN) was available. The children however enjoyed watching the Japanese children's channel. It was possible to watch movies at an extra charge, but we didn't try this feature out.There was a small breakfast buffet costing 500yen per adult, which was served in the ground floor lounge. The options were quite simple: one type of eggs (scrambled or boiled), a rice dish, a meat dish, a soup, a salad, yoghurt and a small selection of breads/buns. It was satisfying enough, though better-value breakfast sets could be had at some of the restaurants near the hotel.One important thing to note is that for stays less than 7 days, the rooms are not cleaned daily - only the towels are replaced and the bins emptied. We were more than happy with this as the bathroom and room were spotless on arrival, and we were careful not to create too much of a mess during our stay. The cleaning staff took into account that there were four of us staying in the room and thoughtfully provided us with plenty of fresh towels each day.

It's tough to review hotels that were just good -- because, I mean, you really shouldn't be at your hotel that much unless that's the main purpose of the trip. So this is a hotel that was clean, friendly and helpful staff, with a decent, if small, breakfast buffet. The room size was adequate for the price. Finding it from Shinjuku station on your first night in Japan may be a bit annoying, but it's not that bad of a walk (although, we had to do it in the rain). Overall, it's a nice place if you're looking for a quick budget solution. There's a 7/11 across the street for US tourists (ATMs that accept US debit cards). And a short walk to the major areas in Shinjuku, including the station.

nice hotel, easy to access from train station nishishinjuku sanchome station. staff was friendly, we had a chance to have a room with nice view and washing machine (quite useful) breakfast was okay,  minor complaint from our side was some dust in the room, if you're allergic it may cause some issues. you can walk to government building just in 10 minutes and have a free visit, (recommended to see during day if you would like to take photos) Wifi was good as usual in many hotels in Japan.There is a McDonalds in the ground floor and supermarket is just across street.

I stayed at this hotels in March during cherry blossom season. It was a great boutique hotel but poor locationHotel locationIt is 3mins walk from A1 Exit Nishi-Shinjuku Gochome Station (Toei Oedo Line). However, since Toei Oedo line runs in a loop, if you are coming from Shinjuku/ginza /ueno direction, you need to transfer at Tochomae station. It is an easy transfer, but it gets frustrated and tired if you are carrying luggage as well as after walking the entire day at Tokyo. Hotel location is extremely important when visiting Tokyo since you will walk a lot! This is the main reason I only gave this hotel 3 stars.The good side is that the hotel located in quiet Japanese neighborhood so that you can experience local people’s daily life. There is lovely temple called kumano shrine, which is 5mins walk from the hotel. It is local temple without tourists. It is worthy to visit. Most of items in the small drugstore besides the hotel is cheaper than those chain one in tourism spot. However, they don’t offer tax-free to foreigners. Hotel room/Service Hotel room is slightly bigger than other hotels I stayed in Tokyo. Room is clean and the service is great! Front desk can communicate well in English.There are Instant Japanese Green tea bag besides the evaluator that you can take with you to the room.  If you have a really relaxing schedule, you can choose this hotel. However, if your schedule is really packed and rush, I will recommend other hotels that are more closed to Shinjuku station.

Less than 2-8 mins walk to restaurants, fast food restaurants, family supermarket, Oedo line. Walking distance to Hilton hotel for free buses to Shinjuku Station. Its just so convenient. But room is a bit small.

Budget hotel but hotel clean. No nearby restaurants apart from McDonald's next door. Small room but en suite. Fine for one night but more and we wished we had paid more. Main issue was location. Possibly better in Tokyo. Bonus having a washer dryer in room

This hotel was very comfortable, nice size room for myself, would even sleep two if need be. Free Wi-Fi, Great private bath with tub!, comfortable bed, wonderful staff, excellent location, all the basic amenities I needed: TV, hair dryer, clean room, nice view, small hotel, very decent basic breakfast, lots of restaurants nearby, subway station close by. Very easy check-in, opening windows, good a/c. I can't say enough. The price was excellent. Out of a hundred hotels I've stayed in, this is my favorite ever. I LOVED the place! A nice park across the street, excellent, excellent, excellent

This is a good service apartment if you wish to do a little cooking and wash your laundry. It was perfect for us as we like to enjoy the fresh food from the supermarket.We had a twin sharing room. As compared to the one we stayed at Nihonbashi, this one is more spacious. There are two small round tables and comfortable chairs which we use for our dinner.The kitchenette with some a removable induction stove, some very simple crockery, refrigerator and a heavy duty washing machine are standard prescriptions. The three-piece bathroom is also spacious. Only strange thing about this chain of service apartment is that they don't change your towels everyday if you stay for more than 6 nights. We stayed for 7 nights. But they gave us double set of towels each, and arranged to change on the 4th day. When we stayed 2 nights at Nihonbashi's branch, they change our towels everyday!The location of this apartment is very convenient. It is a 2 min walk to the Oedo Line (E29 - Nishi-Shinjuku gochome). The main Shinjuku station is about 10-15 min slow walk (slightly uphill). If you don't want to walk uphill, there are buses heading there from a bus stop nearby. Also if you are arriving from the airport and don't want to struggle with your luggage, you can take the airport limousine bus to Hilton Tokyo Hotel and walk (downhill) for about 2 blocks.There are several convenient stores near by and a 24 hr supermarket about 2 min away, and if you want American fast food, MacDonald's is just next door.I will stay here again if I return to Tokyo.

Stayed here for one night in Tokyo, and it was quite pleasant. Reception was warm, rooms were clean (with in-room washer-dryers, which is convenient), and breakfast was decent for about 500 yen. That said, I mistakenly first went to the Tokyu Stay Shinjuku, and that seems like it's in a better location for those desiring a bit of nightlife right outside their hotel entrance. The Tokyu Stay Nishinjuku is in a bit more of a business area, with nothing much exciting immediately around it. That said, it's not far from Shinjuku Town and a good deal for the money in Tokyo.

The Tokyu Stay hotel chain has worked pretty well for us so far, with comfortable rooms & good amenities. However this one didn't quite cut it. Breakfast was unfortunately not at an adjacent Jonathan's (unlike the one in Shibuya & others), instead it seemed basic & served right in the lobby with minimal seating. Though there was a 24hrs McDonalds next door! Located near the business district of nishi shinjuku, this hotel doesn't make a good location for leisure travellers (read: no decent food options at night in the vicinity nor nightlife) A little on the far side from the JR Shinjuku station - a good 15-20 minute walk

Two friends and I stayed three nights at this hotel.The single rooms are very small by European standards. You are literally not able to find space in your room to open a large suit case, hence all three of us opted to leave the suitcases in our beds, even when sleeping in the beds.The bathrooms offers the facillities you would require, however not that much in terms of amenities. Very good water pressure in the shower. Everything was nice and clean. Bathroom towels are changed during your stay, however the room as such is not clean - a fact we were made aware of during check-in.Didn't try the breakfast, however was given the impression that it was quite basic.The reason I give this hotel 4 points is simply due to the value for money. The room rates were quite favourable compared to similar hotels in the area.

We've stayed twice - once in a full size two-king-bed room, once in a more modest "semi-double". The semi-double has a 48" wide bed, which is smaller than an American queen size but bigger than an American "Full" double bed. There's very little extra space in the room for storing your bags and other things but there's enough. The "full size" room is huge and has lots of space. The whole hotel is efficient, friendly, and clean. The location was very convenient for us - it's moments from the nishishinjuku gochome subway station, and an easy 15-20 minute walk from the huge Shinjuku rail station. We loved our stay here and would come back again.

This hotel is very easy to find, and in walking distance of the JR Shinjuku Station. The staff are excellent, very helpful, great English and welcoming. The rooms are large by Japanese standards, very clean and well equipped. We enjoyed breakfast in the mornings. This hotel is great value for money, and I would definitely stay here again

I usually stay at Sunroute Plaza Shinjuku but this time around, it was fully booked for the duration of our stay and we couldn't be bothered to spend time moving between hotels. Another reason was because we needed to do a round of washing when we checked in and the washing facilities at Sunroute were in the basement along the carpark the last time I was there (July 2014) which creeped me out so when I found this place that had a washing machine in the room, i thought we'd give it a try.Upon arriving at 1pm, we were told that check in was at 3pm. This wasn't a major problem as we were used to it but being a chain, we thought they would be a little more flexible. We left our bags with them and headed out for some food and a wander only getting back at around 9pm. They had kindly placed the bags we left with them in the room we were assigned which was a nice touch and check in was faster than them trying to locate my booking earlier in the day.Customer service was minimal at the front desk and you are lucky if someone greets you when you're walking in and out. The lobby is always empty but there's an automatic coffee machine if you're after a quick cuppa before 11pm each day.Now on to the pros and cons:ProsAs mentioned, washing machines are available in every room and they provide you with one packet of washing powder upon check in. If you need more, you can purchase it from them or from the shops close by. It is a washer/dryer combi which makes things easier as there is no room to lay your clothes out to dry. Instructions are also provided to tell you which button to push.There are bathroom amenities for you to take while waiting for the lift in the lobby (cotton buds, hair brush, shower cap, instant tea or coffee etc) so you can take what you need as and when.Toothbrushes and toiletries are provided in the room.The room is also equipped with the standard hairdryer, kettle, mini fridge, cups as well as cutlery and a microwave.The rooms are slightly bigger than your average rooms in Tokyo with a desk chair as well as an armchair and side table but also because of that, there isn't a lot of space for two to move around.The bed is slightly bigger than the standard double beds in Tokyo hotels and more of a queen size which was good.ConsThe quality of the toiletries aren't great. Especially the conditioners so ladies, you might want to buy a bottle of your own from the shops downstairs.Space wise, there really isn't heaps of space for you put your skincare and makeup etc which makes it tricky.A few power points but mainly along the desk so I'd advise you to bring a multi-plug so you can save bringing a whole bag of travel adaptors.We were staying on the third floor and I thought I'd check out if we had any sort of view only to see that we were level with the rooftop of what I think is the connecting building. Only good thing out of that is we were able to open the window for a bit during the day to air the room.The room is only cleaned once a week (every Monday) so if you stay for a week from Monday to Sunday, I doubt you'd get your room cleaned the whole time.They provide you with a 'Do Not Disturb' sign which the housekeeper ignores. On Monday, while i was changing in the room, the housekeeper happily ignored the sign and opened my room door without warning which was not a good start to my day. She later proceeded to apologies profusely but it wasn't a big deal, more an annoyance that the sign was ignored.We tried to be very conscious of our rubbish and put the plastic bottles on the side of the bin so it could be recycled when cleaned, but the housekeeper only emptied the bin and left all empty bottles and food containers we were planning to throw out untouched. The room cleaning was also oddly done with all towels replaced and additional toothbrushes when we didn't use any and they were all just sitting there in the tray but our empty tissue box was left unreplaced. So we came back to the room late at night to 10 toothbrushes and zero tissues. When you have a partner with sinuses, you know that is not ideal.The location of the hotel was also (although two stations away from Shinjuku), quite annoying because if you're taking the metro from Shinjuku, you have to transfer trains one stop away at Tochomae because it is the end of the line. It is about a 10-20 minute walk from the main area but while we were there, my partner wasn't well and it was raining quite a bit so we figured we'd take the subway.Also, if you do take the subway with your luggages and get off at Nishi Shinjuku Gochomae, I'd advise you to use the elevators as it goes straight up rather than trying to go on escalator after escalator. Once you exit the elevator, look for the golden arches of Maccas on the same side of the street on the left and the hotel is right next to it.The area around the hotel is ok with some food places open till very late but it is a residential area so the few shops in the area close around 9ish and it gets quiet. So if you're looking to stay in a vibrant area, this is not it. Maccas is 24/7 though so you'll never get hungry. There's Matsuya and Sukiya if you go past Maccas that also opens till very late (I had a meal at 1am) but not sure if they're 24/7. If you're after curry rice, CoCo Ichibanya is a few doors down from the hotel but closes at midnight.All in all, not a bad hotel but not great. Would probably not stay here again.

I'm really pleased I stayed in this hotel. The location is perfect - about a 15 minute walk from Shinjuku station (pretty much a straight line from the west exit) and only 3 minutes from another station. It was great being within walking distance to Shinjuku's crazyness but being far enough out that it was quiet. It's also a few minutes walk from the Government Metropolitan building, which is free to go up and get a great view of the city. There are some restaurants close by too.The room itself was a good size and beds were comfortable. Having a washing machine/dryer in the room was really useful. The breakfast was good - Japanese breakfast plus croissants and bread. There is also a nice coffee machine that is free to use from 10am (so after breakfast).The rooms are only cleaned after 6 days but they do change the towels and bins every day. We stayed for 4 nights and this wasn't an issue for us at all. They provide a microwave and bowls/plates etc in the room. There are the usual complimentary bathroom things (very nice body wash!) and the free wifi was very good.If I come back to Tokyo I wouldn't consider staying anywhere else. Considering the location, I thought this was a very good value hotel.

We understand that the size of the room is normal for the Tokyo averages but for the price of the room it would have been great that at least the clean once it in 4 nights!. They only come everyday to change the towels.For the rest, we really like the area (not as busy as Shinjuku station area) and only 2 stops away from the metro. The metro is only 3 minutes away from the hotel and the breakfast is good!

Dubai, United Arab Emirates

review_body: This place was easy to find from the nishi-shinjuku gochome station. it was a mere 5mins walk from exit A1. check in time for most Japan hotels are at 3pm and mind you they are very strict about adhering to their 3pm time check in, even at 245pm they would not check you in. (that might have been my only grime bout this hotel). i was at the hotel for 3 nights. they dont change the sheets, nor make the beds if you stay less than 6 nights with the hotel. they however do empty the trash and tidy out the toilets and change the towels (if required). that wasnt much of an issues with us as the room was really clean to begin with.the room came with a small kitchenette and in room washing machine which was really helpful if you wanted to cook and eat in or even wash your clothes if youd travelled long and far with minimal amounts of clothes. the room size was a little small for 2 people and 2 large luggages but we managed anyways. the location was about 5mins by train or 20mins walk to the central shinjuku area. with consideration for its price and location it was pretty value for money considering most hotels in Tokyo were really expensive. enjoyed my stay with the hotel and would probably return if i were looking at staying around the shinjuku area.

Very well located: 2 metro stops or 15 minutes walking from Shinjuku station. Plenty of restaurants and convenience stores in the vicinity. The metro station Nishi-Shinjuku-Gochome (Toei Oedo line) is in 1 minute walking.I got a single bed room and it was quite small, but it's Tokyo standard and was anyway very modern and equipped with everything necessary. There are even a washing machine and a microwave in each room. The wi-fi works very well.I am just a bit disappointed by the cleaning service: if your stay is shorter than 6 days, your room won't be cleaned. Only the trash bin is emptied and the towels are replaced daily.The breakfast is quite poor but it could be worth the additional 500 Yen, as there's no coffee shop in the area.Staff members are kind and helpful and speak decent English.I recommend it for the good rates and the location. There's no touristic sight in close proximity but I could reach any Tokyo district and the Haneda airport easily from there.

Tokyu Stay is near the Oedo Metropolitan Line only 2 stops far from Shinjuku station in a calm place of the Nishishinjuku quarter. There are no cars, no noise and you can also enjoy some good restaurants in few minutes by walk.The hotel and the rooms were really clean and comfortable.Pros:- Clean and comfortable rooms- Location- Cheap price (our fee was also including the breakfast)Cons:- Cleaning of the rooms was only once per week- A lot of the receptions were not so good in speaking in english (I had some troubles dealing with them)

Hotel is in a quiet neighborhood, 200 meters from the nearest metro station, and 50 from the closest park.Breakfast is OK, with a fair choice between Asian and European dishes. You can even get a coffee to go, between 10 and 11. For those not sure if they like Japanese cuisine, there is a 24/7 McDonald's next door.Rooms are quite big for Tokyo standards, and very clean as well. Staff is very friendly, and helpful. Free wi-fi is there as well. Good sleeping on big beds.

This hotel was great. Although a 20 minute walk from Shinjuku station it was always a pleasant trip and we didn't mind too much. The rooms were on the small side (average for Japan) but we expected that. The staff were very friendly. Breakfast was included but was a bit weird - options included juices and yoghurts but also fried rice and chicken...

Recently stayed here for 3 nights and it was just like coming home every day. We had a large twin room with washer-dryer, kitchen sink, microwave, and sitting area with a small couch and 2 additional chairs and a table. Very comfortable, needless to say. The staff here goes beyond in every way - twice they came to my room to show me how to work the air conditioner and washer dryer. Since all the appliances have Japanese instructions, you have to read the manuals which can be a litttle confusing. We borrowed 2 outlet adapters for a deposit.Breakfast was good enough to get you started for the day - coffee, toast, croissants, buns, hard boiled eggs, fried rice and salad.Location was a little far from the main Shinjuku station, especially in the rain. But there is a small NIshi Shinjuku station a few steps from the hotel where you can take it to the Shinjuku station if you have to go far. There is a market just up the street which has a good variety of food if you are too tired to go out. We got sushi and cold noodles the first night when we arrived. Coming from Narita Airport, we took the airport limo bus to the Tokyo HIlton and walked down the street (about two blocks) which was not that easy with one large heavy suitcase. This small hotel really had a personal feel to it and the employees there when above and beyond. Great value considering the breakfast, free wifi and washer dryer.

New York City, New York

review_body: We stayed in this hotel four nights. Coveniently situated 1 km from Shinjuku station or 200 m from a Toei subway station. Clean, modern, very nice and helpful staff. The room was a bit small, but it was clean and had a microwave and a washing machine. Bathroom OK; shower perfect. They do not make the bed if the stay is less than 5 nights. Breakfast OK, nothing fancy, but enough to get you started.

Stayed in a twin room for three nights and we had a great room with plenty of space to relax. The twin room had two large beds as well as a small lounge, two small tables, two sitting chairs, a large desk and a kitchenette. The two of us had plenty of room. The location is good. You can walk to Shinjuku Station in about 15 minutes or walk to nearby subways in a few minutes. There are plenty of food places nearby. We bought some delicious food from the basement of Keio at Shinjuku and heated it up back at our room and sat at our little table and relaxed with a glass of wine from the nearby 7/11 - great meal for cheap price!This hotel is perfect if you want an inexpensive place that has all the amenities and room to relax.You have to make your own bed but they give fresh towels daily and take the rubbish away.I would definitely stay here again because of the room size and location.
